objinfo.printdate: 1795The characteristics of the color printing indicate that this impression is the second one printed in 1795. The hand coloring may have been touched up by Blake shortly before he delivered the print to Thomas Butts in 1805. The first impression in the 1795 printing session is *The Good and Evil Angels* in a private collection (Butlin 324).
objinfo.medium: planographic color printing with water color and pen and ink additions to the impression

provenance.name: Tate Collection
provenance.note: Acquired by Thomas Butts in 1805 from Blake; Thomas Butts, Jr., apparently by inheritance in 1845; Frederick J. Butts, apparently by inheritance in 1862; his widow, c. 1905, by inheritance; sold 2 June 1805 to W. Graham Robertson; given 1939 by Robertson to the Tate Gallery (now Tate Collection).

desc.objtitle: The Good and Evil Angels (Tate Collection), Object 1 (Butlin 323)

objnote.p: The textual context of the earliest version of "The Good and Evil Angels," on Plate 4 of *The Marriage of Heaven and Hell* (1790), offers some insight into its meaning. On Plate 3 of *The Marriage*, Blake introduces the "contraries...the religious call Good & Evil" (Erdman page 34). We can identify the figure on the left in the color printed drawing as the "Evil" angel, shackled on his left ankle and rising before flames. On the right, holding a child apparently struggling to be free, is the "Good" angel. On Plate 4 of *The Marriage*, the "voice of the Devil" continues to explore the binary oppositions of fallen vision and claims that the religious identify "Evil" with "Energy" and "the Body," and the "Good" with "Reason" and the "Soul" (Erdman page 34). In his comments that follow, the Devil does not so much reverse this equation as deny the linked differences themselves, stating that the body is an aspect of soul. The color print may also indicate the fall into the errors of the good/evil, body/soul, energy/reason dualities. The child may thus represent humanity caught between these contending oppositions.
The title, "The Good and Evil Angels," is inscribed in pencil below the design, almost certainly not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two angels representing good and evil occupy opposite sides of the design. The figure on the left, the evil angel, hovers before large flames. He leans forward with arms extended horizontally, palms down and fingers slightly spread. He may be reaching with his left hand toward the child held by the other adult figure. His right leg is extended backwards; a shackle and chain bind his left ankle to the earth below. The evil angel is nude and muscular; he has short, curly hair. The absence of pupils suggests that he is blind. His face is heavily wrinkled, possibly with despair or anger rather than age. On the right, the good angel, a nude, muscular male figure with medium length, flame-like hair, hovers over a shoreline against the backdrop of a rising or setting sun, and holds a child in his arms. The good angel faces forward with his left leg extended backward, but looks to the left, towards the evil angel, with his mouth open in an expression of fear (or at least serious concern). His arms are bent at the elbows, and his right hand grasps the child, while the left holds (or at least touches) the side of the child’s torso. The good angel may be moving the child to the right, out of the reach of the evil angel. The child (apparently male) in the arms of the good angel faces away from the viewer, but with his head turned to left profile and with arms raised vertically, palms out and fingers spread; his left leg is extended. He appears to be looking at the evil angel. He has short, curly hair and a muscular body; his mouth is open in an expression of pain or fear. He may be trying to flee from the evil angel.

component.illusobjdesc: The male evil angel hovers on the left before large flames. He leans forward with his upper body nearly horizontal. His arms are outstretched horizontally with palms down and fingers spread. He may be reaching with his left hand toward the child held by the angel on the right. The evil angel's right leg is extended backward; a shackle that appears to be chained to the ground binds his left ankle. The evil angel is nude and muscular and has short, curly hair. The absence of pupils suggests that he is blind. His face is heavily lined with wrinkles, perhaps with despair or anger rather than age. He may be hovering, rising, or struggling against the chain.
A shackle, apparently chained to the ground, binds the left ankle of the evil angel.

The evil angel hovers on the left before several large flames that seem to originate from the left side of the design and burn diagonally towards the right. Smoke may darken the sky above the flames, which also cast a shadow on the ground below. The right side of the evil angel's torso and part of his right thigh are also darkened by a shadow.

The good angel on the right, a nude, muscular male figure with medium length, flame-like hair, hovers (or strides forward and to the left) over a shore against the backdrop of a rising or setting sun. He holds a child in his arms. The good angel faces forward with his left leg bent slightly at the knee and extended backward, but looks to the left, towards the evil angel, with his mouth open in an expression of fear (or at least serious concern). His feet are prominent; his arms are bent at the elbows and his right hand (fingers slightly spread) grasps the child’s buttocks, while the left holds (or at least touches) the side of the child’s torso. The good angel may be attempting to move the child beyond the reach of the evil angel.

The good angel holds a muscular male child with short, curly hair. The child’s body faces away from the viewer, but his head is turned towards the left; he looks towards the evil angel with his mouth open in an expression of fear. His posture, with arms raised vertically, palms out, with fingers spread and legs extended, also expresses fear. He is probably trying to flee from the evil angel, and perhaps also from the grasp of the good angel who holds him.

The good angel hovers before a sea bordered in the foreground by a shore and in the background by a horizon with a rising or setting sun. White-capped waves strike the apparently sandy shore. Beams of light and a glow of radiance surround the sun. There may be clouds in the sky above and to the left of the head of the good angel.
Slight green coloring on the ground or sand hints at low-growing vegetation, such as grass, lichens, or moss.
